Carlos posee un negocio donde ofrece servicios de reparación para moto taxis, polarizados en vehículos, diseños de calcomanías para vehículos. Carlos busca muchas posibilidades para generar ingresos para su familia, ahora el solicita este crédito por que le ha llegado mucho trabajo de reparación de moto taxis a su negocio y no quiere dejar ir la oportunidad de hacer estos trabajos  por no contar con los repuestos necesarios, es por ello que solicita este crédito para compra repuestos.

loans.use: Comprar repuestos para moto taxis

loans.name: Abejitas Group

texts.es: El grupo “Abejitas” esta representado por la señora Aanneli y conformada por 12 miembros que van cursando juntas ya su tercer ciclo demostrando puntualidad en sus pagos y principalmente ganas de seguir trabando. La presidenta es una persona muy trabajadora ella se dedica a diferentes actividades económicas tiene crianza de patos, también trabaja en  carpintería ella barniza muebles, es una señora muy activa y comprometida con el grupo; las demás socias tienen diferentes actividades como la venta de cosméticos, tejidos en macramé, ropa, comida al servicio de manicura y al entre los varones al servicio de transporte público de pasajeros. Ellas cuentan que hay mucha competencia pero también que tienen clientes fieles a los cuales les gusta su trabajo es duro pero continúan trabajando ya que ellos representan el sustento de sus familias. El crédito esta destinado aumentar sus instrumentos de trabajo así como para la adquisición de mercadería atractiva para la venta otras necesitan el dinero para capitalizarse de nuevo debido a que la mayoría invirtió bastante dinero en sus puestos de trabajo respaldándose en la Fundación Agrocapital para un apoyo económico.
texts.en:
The “Abejitas” Group is led by Sra. Aanneli and consists of 12 members who are starting their third loan cycle together. They have demonstrated that they can make their payments on time and continue working. The president is a hardworking woman who is involved in different businesses, including raising ducks and producing varnished furniture. She is an active woman who is committed to the group.

The other members sell cosmetics, produce macramé fabrics, manufacture clothing, prepare food, and perform manicures. The men are involved in public transportation. Even though they face much competition, the members have loyal customers. Despite the difficulty of their jobs, they enjoy their work and continue to do so because their families depend on them.

Their loan will be used to increase their supplies for their work as well as acquire attractive merchandise for sale. Other members need the money to infuse new capital into their businesses since they have invested enough of their own money to secure vending locations. Therefore, they depend on Fundación Agrocapital for additional financial support.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital for their respective businesses

loans.name: Elsei

texts.en:
Elsei P. is from the village of Esperanza, Kinoguitan Misamis Oriental. She is 47 years old. Elsei is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Elsei runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Elsei has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elsei joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsei is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elsei from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is a 62-year-old single mother of six children aged between 30 and 40 years. None of her children go to school. She resides in and owns a six-room house where she lives with four people. Imelda takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. 

She incurs transportation costs to and from buying food stuff at Owino market. She works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a restaurant selling all types of food in Lubaga Road Kitawuluzi  Zone. She sells both on retail and wholesale. Imelda works six days a week. She receives an average of 30 customers a day.

Her major business challenges include ever-increasing prices of food. Her monthly expenses include feeding the family and medication.  She has been in this business for more than six years and with MCDT for seven years. This is her 20th loan working with the same group. Imelda joined MCDT because it was near her home and also because of working in groups to secure loans. She wants to use this loan to buy more food, such as bananas, potatoes, cassava and beans. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and eventually start a catering firm.

loans.use: To buy more food like bananas, cassava, potatoes and beans

loans.name: Apolonio

texts.en:
Apolonio, 46, is a farmer who dreams of a better life for his family. He is married to Flora and has five children. The eldest child he has is 17 years old. With rice farming, he is determined to provide for the needs of his family and for the education of his children. Aside from rice farming, he also raises ducks as another source of income.

He requested a 15,000 Philippine peso loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., a Kiva partner, to have additional capital to be used for his business. This loan will be helpful to make his business grow.

loans.use: Farm inputs and feed for ducks

loans.name: Jenny

texts.es:
La Señora Jenny, hace dos años que se dedica a la elaboracion D. murales, piñatas, canastas y todo en cotillon, para fiestas infantiles, matrimonios y fiestas D. quince años, todos los días trabaja en los pedidos que tiene desD. las 7:00 D. la mañana, hasta las 10:00 D. la noche y cuando tiene mucho trabajo hasta el amanecer, tiene su taller en su mismo domicilio, como es fin D. año ella necesita capital para preparar sus cotillonerias para las fiestas D. fin D. año, ella está contenta con su trabajo y se siente muy úil puesto que con sus ingresos ayuda al sustento D. su hogar y la educacion D. sus hijos, por lo que esta muy contenta D. contar con el apoyo que le brinda la institucion y esta muy comprometida en no fallar, para ser un ejemplo para su familia.

La Sra. vive en la zon del Plan 3000, que es uno D. los sectores más poblados D. la ciudad D. Santa Cruz. Allí radican una gran cantidad D. pobladores nacidos en esa ciudad conjuncionados con residentes migrantes D. diferentes departamentos Oruro, Cochabamba, La Paz, Sucre, Potosí, etc.
texts.en:
For the last two years, Jenny has been making styrofoam wall displays, piñatas, baskets and all kinds of novelty items for children's parties, weddings, 15th-birthday parties, etc. She begins work on her orders daily at 7am and works until 10pm. Sometimes, when she has a lot of work, she will work until dawn. She has her workshop in her home and, as it is now end of year, she needs financing to prepare her novelty boxes for the end-of-year festivities. She is happy with her work and feels very useful because her earnings help support her household and pay for the education of her children. She is happy to be able to count on the support given by the institution and is committed not to fail so as to set a good example for her family. She lives in the Plan 3000 zone, which is one of the most populous sectors of the city of Santa Cruz. Many residents were born in the city but the neighborhood also attracts residents who have moved to the city from different departments like Oruro, Cochabamba, La Paz, Sucre, Potosí, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa C., 44  years old, is a CEVI client and farmer from Norala, South Cotabato in Mindanao. She manages a small parcel of rice fields, which she hopes could provide her family with adequate supplies of food, clothing and other basic needs. 

She is hoping to receive a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy needed farm supplies in order to increase the size of her harvest and income.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Edna

texts.es:
La Sra. Edna, pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Unión”,  Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Divorciada, tiene 53 años y es madre de 03 hijos; todos independientes.

Su espíritu  luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas de salir adelante con sus propios medios le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes. Nos cuenta que lleva 02 años en este negocio y empezó vendiendo huevos y galletas, poco a poco fue ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad y haciéndose muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  

En la actualidad tiene una clientela ya fidelizada que a diario acude a su tienda a comprar donde cuenta con todo lo necesario que el ama de casa necesita y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con este préstamo de S/ 800.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, utensilios de aseo para el hogar y de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Edna, agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Edna, 53, is a member of the “La Unión” communal bank, which is in Juanjui district, Mariscal Cáceres province, San Martín department. She is divorced and has three children, all of whom are independent. She has always been noted for her fighting spirit and her desire to get ahead motivated her to open her own grocery store. She has had it for two years; she began selling eggs and cookies. Little by little she gained more experience and became better known and well-liked among her customers. Currently, she has regular customers that visit her store daily to buy everything a housewife might need. She, herself, tends to her customers with her characteristic charisma. With this 800 sol loan she will buy sacks of rice and sugar, packages of pasta, cases of milk and preserved fish in a variety of brands, house cleaning products and personal hygiene items to continue providing the best customer service. Edna is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for helping her meet her goals and making her dreams come true.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Ismoil

texts.en:
Ismoil operates a grocery store in his neighborhood. He started his operation seven years ago. He is a 49 year-old father of seven children, three of whom are currently in school. He sells products like rice, canned foods, drinks, cooking oil, assorted biscuits, candies, and evaporated milk. With the loan, he wants to buy more of these and other products to increase his stock of goods. With increased stock and increased varieties, Ismoil hopes to make more income to provide for the educational needs of his children. He would appreciate your assistance very much. He wants to send his children to the university. Ismoil is grateful for your assistance.       


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase additional foods to increase the range of products to sell in his store

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en: Sergei lives in Kherson area, in the village of Gladkivka. He owns several green houses where he grows tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage, etc. He has been in this business for 16 years. Over time, Sergei has gained much experience and many repeat customers, which make his business successful. Sergei is a hard working, disciplined and respectful person. His business goal is to develop his business further to receive more income and give jobs to his fellow village citizens. Sergei would like to borrow 15,000 UAH to purchase film for his green house, seeds, and coal for heating.

loans.use: To purchase film for the green house, seeds & coal

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
A la vivienda del joven Francisco A. le está haciendo falta los acabados del interior, pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder comprar el material y pagarle a la persona que realizara la mejora.
Es por eso que esta solicitando el préstamo y así mejorar la casa donde vive con su mama que es una persona mayor de edad y esta bajo su responsabilidad.
Planea pagar el préstamo con los ingresos que obtiene de su empleo como jefe de meseros de un restaurante.
texts.en:
Francisco A.'s house is still missing its interior finishing touches but he doesn't have funds at present to buy materials and pay labor costs to the person who would do these improvements. For this reason, he is asking for a loan so that he can improve his home where he lives with his mother, who is a senior citizen under his care. He plans to repay the loan with part of his earnings as a head waiter in a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For interior finishing touches.

loans.name: Yonn

texts.en:
The village woman in the photograph is C., age 27. She lives in the province of Kompong Tom, which is the best territory for farming. C. is a married woman who is devoted to her young child, who attends school and depends on her care. She has a small trade selling farming products in bulk. Also, she buys products from farmers to store in her home for a while before selling. Her husband assists her in the business. In addition, the family always takes time to plant rice when the farming season comes. 

C. is taking out her loan to buy a cow to use in the farming business.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Boudy

texts.fr: Boudy D. est âgée de 40ans, elle est mariée et mère de neuf (9) enfants, elle a également la charge de 5 autres enfants qui lui sont confiés. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 7ans et demi. Elle fait de l'élevage de moutons, bœuf, et de chèvres, une activité pour laquelle elle a une bonne expérience pour l'avoir menée depuis plusieurs années. Ses bénéfices lui servent à contribuer à la prise en charge familiale.
texts.en:
Boudy D. is 40 years old, married and mother to nine children. She also cares for 5 other children who have been entrusted to her. She has been a member of the Village Bank for 7 and a half years. She has several years' experience of successfully rearing sheep, cows and goats. The money she earns allows her to contribute to household expenses.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To support her animal rearing business

loans.name: Janargul

texts.en:
Janargul is 40 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. Her oldest daughter attends university and two of her children attend a local secondary school. Janargul operates a fur hat manufacturing business. She has been operating her business since 2000, and has steadily expanded it while gaining valuable experience. 

Janargul originally went into business as a raw materials trader, but later began to manufacture fur hats with wolf, fox and corsac skins bought from a local market called Tirlik. She manufactures well-designed and high quality Kazakh traditional hats with her husband. They use a modern sewing  machine, which helps them to manufacture their hats without any defects. 

Janargul and her husband sell their products door-to-door. They have built a loyal customer base. Most of their customers are tourists or countryside residents. Janargul's monthly sales revenue is 2,000,000 – 2,600,000 tugrugs (~  1430 – 1860 USD). Her monthly profit is 300,000- 450,000 tugrugs (~ 215 - 320 USD). The average cost of one of Janargul's hats is 45,000 – 85,000 tugrugs (~  32 - 60 USD), and the profit per hat is 20,000 tugrugs (~  15 USD). 

Janargul has a great business mind. She is well organized person with good communication skills. She says, “I always prefer to produce high quality products for my customers.” She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase raw materials to manufacture a large amount of hats in anticipation of her province's  70th  anniversary, when many tourists are expected to arrive.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make fur hats

loans.name: Manos Juntas Rumichaca Alta Group

texts.es:
Vilma, tiene 32 años, es conviviente, tiene  cuatro hijos y es natural D. la Ciudad D. Urubamba departamento del Cusco. 

“Vilma es fundadora del banco comunal Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca D. la Unidad D. Micro finanzas D. la  Asociación Arariwa”.

Vilma nos cuenta. - En mi banco comunal “Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca”  somos 12 integrantes (9 mujeres y 3 varones), fui elegida como la presidenta y las reuniones  son cada treinta días en mi casa y en esta oportunidad  me eligieron a mí como representante del banco comunal para dar mi testimonio D. mi principal actividad económica.  

Vilma  su principal actividad económica es la elaboración D. jora, ella tiene contrata con la señora Teresa  a quien le venD. la jora. Su actividad económica complementaria es confeccionar chompas D. lana a pedido del cliente. Vilma requiere el préstamo para comprar maíz  y lana. Ya son  2  años que trabaja en el negocio y le va muy bien.
 
Vilma  permanece en el banco comunal porque quiere aprender a ser responsable con el dinero y saber invertir bien el dinero en su negocio.|

La mayoría D. los socios son comerciantes por ejemplo  algunos se dedican a la crianza D. animales menores, venta D. bebidas, venta D., comestibles, venta D. chicha D. jora y venta D. chompas y otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo son artistas,  empleados públicos D. la municipalidad D. Urubamba, empleado del Hotel Inti Quilla, etc. 

La ciudad D. Urubamba se encuentra a una hora y diez minutos D. la ciudad del Cusco.
texts.en:
Vilma, 32, lives with a partner and has 4 children. She is a native of the city of Urubamba, in the Cusco department. Vilma is the founder of the communal bank "Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca," which is in the Unidad Microfinanza Arariwa that is part of the larger umbrella Asociación Arariwa. Vilma tells us "in my communal bank “Manos Juntas D. Rumichaca” we have 12 members (9 women and 3 men.) I was elected president, and the group meets every 30 days in my house. This time they chose me as the representative of the bank to give my testimony of my principal economic activity." Vilma's main economic activity is making chicha D. jora (a traditional Peruvian beverage maD. from roasted corn.) She has a contract with Señora Teresa to whom she sells the jora. She also makes woolen jackets to order for her customers. Vilma needs a loan to buy corn and firewood. She has already worked for 2 years in this business, and it is going very well. Vilma belongs to the communal bank because she wants to learn how to be responsible with money and to invest well in her business. The majority of the other members are merchants, for example: some are engaged in raising young livestock, others sell drinks, food, chicha D. jora, jackets, and other members proviD. services, such as: artists, employees of the municipality of Urubamba, employees of the Hotel Inti Quilla, etc. The city of Urubamba is located an hour and 10 minutes from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vilma needs a loan to buy firewood and corn

loans.name: Ponciano

texts.en:
Ponciano C. is from Cogon Ozamiz City. He is 56 years old. Ponciano is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Ponciano owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motor transport services. Ponciano has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ponciano joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ponciano has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. Ponciano is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Ponciano from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair existing vehicle for better service

loans.name: Umeda

texts.en:
J. Umeda is a woman who, on a daily basis, seeks her children's advancement. She works with great effort for them and wants to continue to do so to build an improved and promising future. Ever since Umeda was a little girl, she has been devoted to her farming activities. She was raised this way and it has been a stable source of income until now. She must start her farming chores very early in the day. Now that it is sowing season, she works hard to sow and tend the fields. She hopes that this time the harvest will be productive.

Umeda is asking for this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers in order to obtain a very good quantity and quality of onions, tomatoes, cucumbers and wheat. Let’s show solidarity for this selfless mother who looks for what is best for her children. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Asiaha

texts.en:
Asiaha B. is a 32-year-old married woman. To earn a living, her husband is a teacher. She and her husband have 3 children, two of whom are in school. Asiaha is currently in the business of selling bags of groundnuts and maize flour at the market. She is now requesting a loan in the amount of $175 to stock more nuts to sell. With the expected additional profits generated as a result of the loan, she hopes to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights, and legal services. All of these services are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional bags of groundnuts

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica A. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 57 years old. Monica is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Monica owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Monica has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5,300 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Monica joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Monica is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Monica from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Kuñakuera Katupyry Group

texts.es:
El contacto para el inicio del presente comité fue la señora Mirna quien ya conocia el programa D. Comite D. Mujeres Emprendedoras e invito y organizo a sus amigas para formar parte D. comite y hasta la actualidad siguen trabajando, y se encuentran contentas con sus trabajos. 
La sra. Mirna C. obtiene buenos ingresos mediante la venta D. ropas, tiene su clientela ya formada y debido a la temporada D. invierno aumentó su demanda por el frío.
Deseando incrementar sus ingresos quiere invertir en más compra al por mayor D. prendas D. vestir como pantalones, tricotas, camperas, remeras, medias, bufandas, gorros, etc. al por mayor para venta al detalle.
texts.en:
The contact person for the establishment of the current committee was Ms. Mirna, who was already familiar with the Comite D. Mujeres Emprendedoras (Committee of Enterprising Women) Program. She invited and organized her friends to form the group, which has been functioning since then. The group members are satisfied with their jobs.

Ms. Mirna C. earns a living via her apparel business. She has established her client base, and due to the winter season, demand has increased because of the cold weather.

Hoping to increase her income, she would like to invest in purchasing apparel such as pants, sweaters, jackets, T-shirts, socks, scarves, caps, etc. both wholesale and retail.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wholesale and retail apparel
